pullRequest.body:
Instead of inferring `AddCommGroup`, `Module`, etc. instances for `AdicCompletion I M` from being a submodule, we explicitly spell out the definitions to improve performance.

Also marks some definitions as `noncomputable` to save time spent on compilation.

See https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Adic.20completion.20is.20slow.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks, and is labeled with `awaiting-review`.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [7330fdbaf7](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/14534/commits/7330fdbaf720a85e47d8d150f10f7f08ba8afd72)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ incl`
`+ instance : Add (AdicCauchySequence I M)`
`+ instance : Add (AdicCompletion I M)`
`+ instance : AddCommGroup (AdicCauchySequence I M) := by`
`+ instance : IntCast (AdicCauchySequence I R)`
`+ instance : IntCast (AdicCompletion I R)`
`+ instance : Mul (AdicCauchySequence I R)`
`+ instance : Mul (AdicCompletion I R)`
`+ instance : NatCast (AdicCauchySequence I R)`
`+ instance : NatCast (AdicCompletion I R)`
`+ instance : Neg (AdicCauchySequence I M)`
`+ instance : Neg (AdicCompletion I M)`
`+ instance : One (AdicCauchySequence I R)`
`+ instance : One (AdicCompletion I R)`
`+ instance : Pow (AdicCauchySequence I R) ℕ`
`+ instance : Pow (AdicCompletion I R) ℕ`
`+ instance : SMul R (AdicCauchySequence I M)`
`+ instance : SMul R (AdicCompletion I M)`
`+ instance : SMul ℕ (AdicCauchySequence I M)`
`+ instance : SMul ℕ (AdicCompletion I M)`
`+ instance : SMul ℤ (AdicCauchySequence I M)`
`+ instance : SMul ℤ (AdicCompletion I M)`
`+ instance : Sub (AdicCauchySequence I M)`
`+ instance : Sub (AdicCompletion I M)`
`+ instance : Zero (AdicCauchySequence I M)`
`+ instance : Zero (AdicCompletion I M)`
`+ neg`
`+ nsmul`
`+ pow`
`+ sub`
`+ transitionMap_map_pow`
`+ zsmul`
`- instance : AddCommGroup (AdicCauchySequence I M)`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/79b6d1d7-9ac7-4e3f-b478-605edce197d9) for commit db687bff03477d244335979907e5c519d1d04cee.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/2983abee-d37f-4773-ace1-4f30c7ff1087/to/79b6d1d7-9ac7-4e3f-b478-605edce197d9) against commit 86414a80146a3735f0ce18dfcfa3dc88e6b3baf8:
```diff
  Benchmark                                          Metric         Change
  ========================================================================
- ~Mathlib.RingTheory.AdicCompletion.Algebra         instructions    15.4%
- ~Mathlib.RingTheory.AdicCompletion.Basic           instructions    29.5%
+ ~Mathlib.RingTheory.AdicCompletion.Functoriality   instructions   -61.6%
```
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/c6d0302f-c61c-4573-8007-f05dd3325800) for commit ddef0a4199079976a7adfa808af73e663a20fa94.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/2983abee-d37f-4773-ace1-4f30c7ff1087/to/c6d0302f-c61c-4573-8007-f05dd3325800) against commit 86414a80146a3735f0ce18dfcfa3dc88e6b3baf8:
```diff
  Benchmark                                    Metric         Change
  ==================================================================
- ~Mathlib.RingTheory.AdicCompletion.Algebra   instructions    15.4%
- ~Mathlib.RingTheory.AdicCompletion.Basic     instructions    29.5%
```
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/ebe8fac4-5f88-452e-b1de-6be38066e8c3) for commit 20fe104587d1c65ef3f83a6b2e1d23564a72ac62.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/2983abee-d37f-4773-ace1-4f30c7ff1087/to/ebe8fac4-5f88-452e-b1de-6be38066e8c3) against commit 86414a80146a3735f0ce18dfcfa3dc88e6b3baf8:
```diff
  Benchmark                                          Metric         Change
  ========================================================================
- ~Mathlib.RingTheory.AdicCompletion.Algebra         instructions    28.6%
- ~Mathlib.RingTheory.AdicCompletion.Basic           instructions    47.8%
+ ~Mathlib.RingTheory.AdicCompletion.Functoriality   instructions   -60.3%
```
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/b0082dda-fd70-42fc-9272-c00023ba5a11) for commit 6b20ecb7b47f8fb9cdf16327a906945b83fe1232.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/2983abee-d37f-4773-ace1-4f30c7ff1087/to/b0082dda-fd70-42fc-9272-c00023ba5a11) against commit 86414a80146a3735f0ce18dfcfa3dc88e6b3baf8:
```diff
  Benchmark                                          Metric         Change
  ========================================================================
- ~Mathlib.RingTheory.AdicCompletion.Algebra         instructions    27.9%
- ~Mathlib.RingTheory.AdicCompletion.Basic           instructions    34.4%
+ ~Mathlib.RingTheory.AdicCompletion.Functoriality   instructions   -61.7%
```
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/e4fe4920-53cc-4e60-b239-166eb78576f6) for commit 571a2f205fc347b13f0d820b4c1975cfb19eaa8a.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/2983abee-d37f-4773-ace1-4f30c7ff1087/to/e4fe4920-53cc-4e60-b239-166eb78576f6) against commit 86414a80146a3735f0ce18dfcfa3dc88e6b3baf8:
```diff
  Benchmark                                          Metric         Change
  ========================================================================
- ~Mathlib.RingTheory.AdicCompletion.Algebra         instructions    30.9%
- ~Mathlib.RingTheory.AdicCompletion.Basic           instructions    36.4%
+ ~Mathlib.RingTheory.AdicCompletion.Functoriality   instructions   -61.7%
```

I now have benchmarks of making everything irreducible: The difference is insignificant, only significant change is in the `Algebra` file which gets slightly slower by making everything irreducible:
http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/e7b27246-a3e6-496a-b552-ff4b45c7236e/to/a50cfe65-06b9-429a-b2ed-ef196015bb23?hash1=55cf90705c3509ab5da127b7ecd4db0e147af667

But of course, in the slowest lemma of the `AsTensorProduct` file I currently have two `unseal`s, see above. @mattrobball
Let me actually open up the file. I will need some time though

```lean
add_smul r s x := by
    dsimp 
    ext n
    simp only [coe_eval, smul_eval, map_add, add_smul, val_add]
```
seems to help around L250. 

Also, why were the `simp` attributes removed?

> ```lean
> add_smul r s x := by
>     dsimp 
>     ext n
>     simp only [coe_eval, smul_eval, map_add, add_smul, val_add]
> ```
> 
> seems to help around L250.
> 
> Also, why were the `simp` attributes removed?

L250 of which file? And which `simp` attributes?
Sorry, I've only opened `Algebra` and I can't add comments on unchanged code :(

> Sorry, I've only opened `Algebra` and I can't add comments on unchanged code :(

I am counting heartbeats there with `count_heartbeats in` and adding the `dsimp` increases heartbeats (very sligthly) from 25125 to 25250. Am I missing something?
Sorry I was on the wrong declaration: `AdicCompletion.module` at L312

> Sorry I was on the wrong declaration: `AdicCompletion.module` at L312

Now I am confused, at which version are you looking? In the current one, the `Algebra` file only has 274 lines (Note that I reverted the two commits making everything `irreducible`).
It is out-dated but `AdicCompletion.module` didn't change its name right?

> It is out-dated but `AdicCompletion.module` didn't change its name right?

Ah yes, no it did not change its name, but then adding the `dsimp` does not seem to make a significant difference to `count_heartbeats in`.
Oh well, it was minor I think anyway
So should I go for a final benchmark?
There is a good chance it won't make it in without using the `Function.Injective` constructors. We should test that fully first

I had tried out the version with `Function.Injective` constructors above, but it was significantly slower. See this comparison: http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/04e26275-26be-4d08-8dd1-ffeb4e23bd0e/to/e7b27246-a3e6-496a-b552-ff4b45c7236e?hash2=55cf90705c3509ab5da127b7ecd4db0e147af667

The first run is with `Function.Injective` constructors and the second one without.
Anything else I should test?
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/2050f506-c00a-4a7c-baf2-28c2f8631bd7) for commit 400c96f095557024ecc8aa405d49b64913244fcf.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/2983abee-d37f-4773-ace1-4f30c7ff1087/to/2050f506-c00a-4a7c-baf2-28c2f8631bd7) against commit 86414a80146a3735f0ce18dfcfa3dc88e6b3baf8:
```diff
  Benchmark                                          Metric         Change
  ========================================================================
+ ~Mathlib.RingTheory.AdicCompletion.Algebra         instructions   -15.3%
+ ~Mathlib.RingTheory.AdicCompletion.Functoriality   instructions   -64.1%
```
What's the effect on `AsTensorProduct`?
Benchmark is upcoming. My local one looks very good, i.e. comparable to the performance with explicit instances.

Benchmark is there. This is the comparsion:

http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/e7b27246-a3e6-496a-b552-ff4b45c7236e/to/74e2d180-1ac7-47c1-9b6e-c7589ce1cd90?hash1=abf5c5635c9bde7cefa76b2c18405067b604e089

First commit: manual instances
Second commit: `Function.Injective` constructors with `fast_instance%`.

I think this looks promising, so I'll revert the commits adding the `fast_instance%` stuff and we add them back in later when the #11521 lands. What do you think @mattrobball ?
Also please make a separate dependent PR with the `fast_instance` insertions also so we can quickly put them back when that PR lands

> Also please make a separate dependent PR with the `fast_instance` insertions also so we can quickly put them back when that PR lands

Since #11521 currently has merge conflicts, what should I do to create the dependent PR? Maybe from #11521 the actual `fast_instance%` code should be split of, otherwise it will collect merge conflicts all the time.
I forgot it wasn't just the single file. I'll split it later today.
Anything else I should do for this PR to be merged?

I don't think so. Thanks for your patience.

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9894750687/job/27333023627)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9894750687/job/27333024430)
Thanks a lot for the guidance and for helping analyzing this!
These are still valuable I think
Can you make the data instances `irreducible`?
Done.
`Function.Injective.commRing` might help
I changed it, not entirely sure its better now though.

I did another benchmark comparing the version with `Function.Injective.commRing` and the manual one: http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/04e26275-26be-4d08-8dd1-ffeb4e23bd0e/to/e7b27246-a3e6-496a-b552-ff4b45c7236e?hash2=55cf90705c3509ab5da127b7ecd4db0e147af667
It seems the manual one is significantly faster, so I suggest we leave it at this.

I am not sure if the `irreducible` attribute does anything on an instance. The pattern is 
```suggestion
@[irreducible]
def mul (x y : AdicCompletion I R) : AdicCompletion I R := ⟨x.val * y.val, by simp [x.property, y.property]⟩

instance instMul : Mul (AdicCompletion I R) where 
  mul := mul 
```
so Lean can never unfold `mul`
Should I do this for every data field? Also `zero`, `one`, etc.?
I think it is a worth a test.
Lean might try to unfold `toFun` unnecessarily during unification checks. You could try hoisting it out as a separate declaration.
I also wonder if there is a better syntactical spelling for `nsmul` and `zsmul` fields. Being data, they could also be made irreducible to avoid unfolding.

I think the two `unseal`s here are a problem: In the other PR in the `AsTensorProduct` file, I had to add the same `unseal`s because Lean can no longer identify these two instances as equal:
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/abf5c5635c9bde7cefa76b2c18405067b604e089/Mathlib/RingTheory/AdicCompletion/AsTensorProduct.lean#L133-L138 Is there anything I can do about this? Or does it mean we can't make `mul` and `smul'` irreducible?

For future reference, this partially defeats the purpose of `irreducible`. You can do a more targeted `unseal X in` in a proof step I believe. Or you can wrap your term in `with_unfolding_all` to achieve a similar effect
I thought that the `unseal` here is confined to this section? But you are saying that even this is too big of a scope?

You are correct, it is. But with the definition open, Lean will try to do extra work there. Less than overall, but still can be avoided. 

The pattern is usually: 
- make `@[irreducible] def X` 
- develop minimal necessary API for `X` either `unseal`ing or `with_all_unfolding`
- never `unseal` again 

So in general, I would never see an `unseal X` unless it ended in an `in`

I see. But in the case above where I need `unseal` to see that the two `AdicCompletion I R`-module instances on `AdicCompletion I R` are defeq, I seem to be bound to use `unseal` whenever they come up. Is this correct or can I make this work somehow?
If you are doing it by hand, then yes you are stuck with that. If it is happening in instance synthesis, it is much worse.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(RingTheory/AdicCompletion): manual instances
